TEXT.English: [TAB]Manichaeism was one of the major Iranian Gnostic religions, originating in Sassanid Persia.[NEWLINE][TAB]Although most of the original writings of the founding prophet Mani (c. 216-276 AD) have been lost, numerous translations and fragmentary texts have survived. Manichaeism taught an elaborate cosmology describing the struggle between a good, spiritual world of light, and an evil, material world of darkness. The 4th Century Acta Archelai of Christian writer Hegemonius depicts a strong anti-semitism in Mani's teaching.[NEWLINE][TAB]Through an ongoing process which takes place in human history, light is gradually removed from the world of matter and returned to the world of light from which it came. Its beliefs can be seen as a synthesis of Christianity, Zoroastrianism and Buddhism.[NEWLINE][TAB]Manichaeism thrived between the third and seventh centuries, and at its height was one of the most widespread religions in the world. Manichaean churches and scriptures existed as far east as China and as far west as the Roman Empire. Manichaeism survived longer in the east, and appears to have finally faded away after the 14th century in southern China, contemporary to the decline in China of the Church of the East - see Ming Dynasty.[NEWLINE][TAB]The original, but now lost, six sacred books of Manichaeism were composed in Syriac Aramaic, and translated into other languages to help spread the religion. As they spread to the east, the Manichaean writings passed through Middle Persian, Parthian, Sogdian, Tocharian and ultimately Uyghur and Chinese translations. As they spread to the west, they were translated into Greek, Coptic, and Latin. The spread and success of Manichaeism were seen as a threat to other religions, and it was widely persecuted in Christian, Zoroastrian, Islamic, and Buddhist cultures.

[TAB]The Hellenic religion, also referred to as Greek mythology, comprises an enormous body of stories about gods, goddesses, and heroes. These stories date back many centuries, preserved in pre-literate Greece through oral tradition. The Hellenic religion was polytheistic in nature, with innumerable local nature deities in addition to the major Olympian gods and goddesses. The Greek gods were human in form but possessed supernatural powers; they were born from other gods but never aged, they were immortal, could travel enormous distances instantly, speak through humans with or without their knowledge, etc. Some gods were the personified aspects of natural forces (for example, Helios was literally the god of the sun) while others had complex personalities and multiple functions associated with them (Apollo is probably the best example). [PARAGRAPH:1]The gods and goddesses were all related to one another as part of one large family, but there were clear generations of gods, and their interactions with each other were sometimes violent. For example, the Olympian gods had reached their place of dominance by casting out an earlier generation of gods and goddesses known as the Titans. This may be a mythical reflection of the struggle between the Greeks and the earlier culture that they displaced when arriving in the Peloponnesus around roughly 1000 BC. [PARAGRAPH:1]In addition to stories about gods, the Hellenic religion was also full of great sagas about the deeds of heroes, many of whom possessed a divine parent. Stories abound about figures such as Heracles, Perseus, Jason, and the characters of the Iliad. These humans frequently interacted with gods and even bested them at times. Many of the heroes were held in great esteem by the Greeks, especially "noble" characters such as Achilles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Although some of the well-educated Greeks had their doubts about the existence of the gods, the vast majority of Greeks did not question the validity of the stories. The Greeks used their religion to explain the doings of the natural world and their own origins; it was a source of pride to trace one's lineage or the founding of one's city to the actions of a god. [PARAGRAPH:1]Archaeology and linguistic analysis suggests that the Hellenic religion was heavily influenced by other religions. For example, the Greek Zeus, Roman Jupiter, Germanic Tyr, and Sanskrit Dyaus are all sky gods that share a common Indo-European origin sometime in the distant past. Other gods were borrowed or influenced from Near Eastern religions; Aphrodite possessed a very similar function to the Semitic goddesses Ishtar and Astarte. During the Hellenic period and afterwards, the Greek religion spread across much of the Mediterranean and Near East, influencing many of the previously existing religions and giving rise to new syncretistic mystery cults. Although the Hellenic religion is no longer followed, it continues to provide inspiration for artists throughout the world.
TEXT.French: [TAB]La religion hellénique, à laquelle on fait le plus souvent référence sous l'appellation de mythologie grecque, comprend un grand nombre de légendes sur les dieux, déesses et héros. Certaines de ces légendes remontent à plusieurs siècles, ayant été transmises par la tradition orale. La religion hellénique est polythéiste, avec d'innombrables divinités locales de la nature en plus des principaux dieux du panthéon olympien. Les dieux grecs ont forme humaine mais possèdent des pouvoirs surnaturels, ont été engendrés par d'autres dieux mais ne vieillissent pas, ils sont immortels, peuvent voyager sur de très grandes distances instantanément, parler à travers les humains (parfois sans même que ceux-ci s'en aperçoivent), etc. Certains dieux sont les personnifications des forces de la nature (Hélios étant littéralement le dieu du soleil) alors que d'autres ont des personnalités complexes et sont associés à de multiples fonctions (Apollon en étant le meilleur exemple). [PARAGRAPH:1]Dieux et déesses sont tous parents d'une même grande famille, mais il existe des générations distinctes de dieux, et leurs interactions sont parfois très violentes. Le fait est que les dieux olympiens n'occupent leur position dominante qu'après avoir chassé une première génération de dieux appelés les Titans. Cela reflète sans doute le chevauchement culturel mythologique existant entre les Grecs et la civilisation précédente, chassée à leur arrivée dans le Péloponnèse aux alentours de 1000 av. J.-C.. [PARAGRAPH:1]Outre de nombreuses légendes sur les dieux, la tradition orale hellénique est riche de grandes sagas relatant les hauts faits de héros humains, dont un certain nombre ont une ascendance divine. On pense notamment aux légendes d'Héraclès, de Persée, de Jason et des personnages de l'Iliade. Ces mortels entrent souvent en conflit avec des dieux et en triomphent parfois. Nombre d'entre eux, surtout s'ils sont nobles et puissants comme Achille, sont tenus en haute estime par les Grecs. [PARAGRAPH:1] Même si certains des Grecs éduqués entretiennent quelques doutes à propos de la réalité dessinée par la religion hellénique, la grande majorité de la population accepte sans réserve la mythologie comme seule vérité. Les Grecs s'appuient sur leur religion pour expliquer les phénomènes naturels et leurs propres origines, et c'est une source de grande fierté que de pouvoir associer une lignée ou la fondation d'une cité aux actions d'un dieu.[PARAGRAPH:1] Les résultats des recherches archéologiques et linguistiques laissent penser que la religion hellénique a été très influencée par d'autres religions. C'est ainsi que le dieu grec Zeus, le dieu romain Jupiter, le dieu germain Tyr et le dieu sanskrit Dyaus sont tous des dieux du ciel, et il est probable qu'ils partagent tous une même lointaine origine indo-européenne. Les Grecs empruntent librement des dieux à d'autres cultes du Proche-Orient, c'est ainsi qu'Aphrodite a des fonctions très proches de celles des déesses sémites Ishtar et Astarté. Au cours de l'époque hellénique et par la suite, la religion grecque se répand à travers la plus grande partie de la Méditerranée et du Proche-Orient, influençant nombre des cultes déjà existants et donnant naissance à de nouveaux cultes syncrétistes. Bien que la religion grecque ne soit plus pratiquée de nos jours, ses mythologies continuent d'enflammer les imaginations et d'illuminer les esprits.
TEXT.German: [TAB]Die hellenistische Religion der Antike, auch als griechische Mythologie bezeichnet, umfasste einen enormen Fundus an Götter- und Heldensagen. Diese Geschichten datieren viele Jahrhunderte zurück und blieben in der präliterarischen Zeit durch mündliche Überlieferung erhalten. Der hellenistische Glaube war angesichts der vielen Götter und Göttinnen des Olymps sowie zahlloser regionaler Naturgottheiten extrem polytheistisch geprägt. Die griechischen Götter wurden in der Regel in menschlicher Form dargestellt, besaßen allerdings übernatürliche Kräfte. Sie wurden von anderen Gottheiten geboren, alterten nicht, waren unsterblich, konnten im Nu enorme Entfernungen überwinden, sprachen durch die Menschen (mit oder ohne deren Wissen) etc. Einige Götter verkörperten Naturgewalten (zum Beispiel war Helios im wörtlichen Sinne der Gott der Sonne), während andere komplexe Persönlichkeitsstrukturen aufwiesen und zahlreiche Funktionen wahrnahmen (zum Beispiel Apollon). [PARAGRAPH:1]Als Teil einer großen Familie waren die Götter und Göttinnen alle irgendwie miteinander verwandt, aber es gab eine klare Generationeneinteilung und manchmal bekämpften sie sich auch gegenseitig. Zum Beispiel sollen die Götter des Olymps ihre Vorherrschaft durch den Sturz der vorangehenden Göttergeneration, der so genannten Titanen, gesichert haben. Hierbei könnte es sich um eine mythische Darstellung der kulturellen Überschneidung zwischen den Griechen und der früheren Population in dieser Region handeln, die sie bei der Ankunft auf dem Peleponnes um 1000 vor Christus vertrieben hatten. [PARAGRAPH:1]Neben den vielen Göttergeschichten wurde die griechische Religion auch von zahlreichen grandiosen Sagen über die Abenteuer verschiedener Helden beeinflusst, von denen viele zumindest ein göttliches Elternteil besaßen. Die Erzählungen handelten von heldenhaften Persönlichkeiten wie Herakles, Perseus, Jason sowie den Charakteren der Ilias und inspirierten viele griechische Künstler späterer Generationen. Diese Helden in Menschengestalt kamen häufig mit den Göttern in Kontakt, übertrumpften sie bisweilen sogar und wurden von den Griechen meist hoch geschätzt, insbesondere so ehrenhafte Persönlichkeiten wie zum Beispiel Achilles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Einige der griechischen Gelehrten hatten durchaus Zweifel an dem Wahrheitsgehalt der griechischen Mythologie, dennoch stellte der überwiegende Teil der Bevölkerung die Stichhaltigkeit der überlieferten Legenden nicht in Frage. Die Griechen nutzten ihre Religion, um natürliche Vorgänge und auch ihren eigenen Ursprung zu erklären. Man war stolz darauf, wenn man seine eigene Herkunft oder die Gründung seiner Heimatstadt auf das Einwirken eines Gottes zurückführen konnte. [PARAGRAPH:1]Archäologische und sprachliche Untersuchungen haben ergeben, dass die griechische Religion stark von anderen Religionen beeinflusst war. Zum Beispiel stellen der griechische Gott Zeus, der römische Gott Jupiter, der germanische Gott Tyr und der Sanskrit-Gott Dyaus allesamt Himmelsgötter dar, die irgendwann in der fernen Vergangenheit einen gemeinsamen indo-europäischen Ursprung hatten. Andere Götter wurden von den Religionen im Nahen Osten "ausgeborgt" oder zumindest beeinflusst: Aphrodite besaß frappierend ähnliche Eigenschaften und Funktionen wie die semitischen Göttinnen Ishtar und Astarte. Während der hellenischen Periode und auch danach kam es zu einer starken Verbreitung der griechischen Mythologie über große Teile des Mittelmeerraums und des Nahen Ostens. Sie beeinflusste viele der bereits existierenden Religionen und ebnete den Weg für die Entstehung neuer synkretistischer Mysterienkulte. Obwohl die griechische Religion des hellenistischen Zeitalters heute nicht mehr in dieser Form praktiziert wird, lassen sich auch heute noch Künstler in aller Welt von ihr inspirieren.
TEXT.Italian: [TAB]La religione ellenica, nota anche come "mitologia greca", è composta da un'enorme serie di storie di dei, dee ed eroi, tramandate a lungo tempo oralmente nell'era pre-letteraria. La religione ellenica era politeistica e oltre agli dei e alle dee dell'Olimpo comprendeva innumerevoli divinità naturali locali. Le divinità greche avevano aspetto umano ma erano dotate di poteri soprannaturali; pur nascendo (da altre divinità) non invecchiavano ed erano immortali, potevano coprire enormi distanze istantaneamente, parlare attraverso gli uomini con o senza la loro consapevolezza, ecc. Alcune divinità erano la personificazione di forze naturali (per esempio, Elio era letteralmente il dio del sole), mentre altre avevano personalità complesse e numerose funzioni (Apollo ne è forse il miglior esempio).[PARAGRAPH:1]Le divinità avevano fra loro vincoli di parentela e formavano una grande famiglia, ma potevano distinguersi diverse generazioni, le cui interazioni con le altre avevano spesso esiti violenti. Per fare un esempio, gli dei olimpici avevano raggiunto la loro posizione di dominio estromettendo la precedente generazione dei Titani. Questo fenomeno potrebbe essere un riflesso culturale di ciò che avvenne quando i Greci si sostituirono alla popolazione locale quando giunsero nel Peloponneso intorno al 1000 a.C. [PARAGRAPH:1]Oltre alle storie sugli dei, la mitologia greca è piena di grandi saghe che narrano le gesta di eroi, molti dei quali avevano genitori divini. I miti di Ercole, Perseo, Giasone e le storie dei protagonisti dell'Iliade furono spesso oggetto di rielaborazione da parte degli artisti greci successivi. Si trattava di uomini che interagivano spesso con gli dei, a volte superandoli. Molti di loro erano enormemente stimati dai Greci, soprattutto se "nobili" come Achille.[PARAGRAPH:1]Anche se i Greci meglio istruiti avevano i loro dubbi sul fondamento della religione ellenica, il popolo non metteva in dubbio la veridicità delle storie. I Greci usarono la loro religione per spiegare i fenomeni naturali e le proprie origini; era fonte di orgoglio il fatto che la propria ascendenza o la fondazione della propria città potessero essere fatte risalire a un atto divino. [PARAGRAPH:1]Le analisi archeologiche e linguistiche suggeriscono che la religione ellenica abbia subito una pesante influenza da parte di altre religioni. Per esempio, il dio greco Zeus, il dio romano Giove, il dio germanico Tyr e il dio sanscrito Dyaus sono tutte divinità del cielo che condividono un'origine indo-europea risalente a chissà quando nel passato. Altre divinità furono prese in prestito o influenzate dalle religioni del Vicinio Oriente: Afrodite aveva una funzione simile a quella delle semitiche Ishtar e Astarte. Nel corso del periodo ellenico e anche dopo, la religione greca si diffuse nel Mediterraneo e nel Vicino Oriente, influenzando a sua volta molte religioni pre-esistenti e facendo nascere nuovi culti mistici sincretici. Anche se oggi si tratta di una religione morta, la mitologia greca ha ispirato gli artisti per migliaia di anni.
TEXT.Spanish: [TAB]La religión helénica, también conocida como mitología griega, comprende un cuerpo enorme de narraciones sobre los dioses y héroes. Estas historias tenían muchos siglos de antigüedad y, hasta la aparición de la escritura en Grecia, se conservaron mediante la tradición oral. De naturaleza politeísta, contaba con un sinfín de deidades naturales locales, además de los principales dioses y diosas del Olimpo. Los dioses griegos tenían forma humana, pero poseían poderes sobrenaturales; eran engendrados por otros dioses, pero nunca envejecían, no podían morir, podían cruzar enormes distancias al instante, hablaban a través de los humanos con o sin su consentimiento, etc. Algunos de ellos eran los aspectos personificados de las fuerzas de la naturaleza (Helios, por ejemplo, era literalmente el dios del sol) mientras que otros poseían personalidades complejas y funciones múltiples (seguramente Apolo sea el mejor ejemplo). [PARAGRAPH:1]Todos los dioses pertenecían a una gran familia, pero había varias generaciones diferenciadas y su interacción era en muchas ocasiones violenta. Los dioses del Olimpo, por ejemplo, habían alcanzado su posición de predominio tras expulsar a una generación anterior de dioses y diosas (los titanes). Esto bien pudiera ser una transposición mitológica de la lucha entre los griegos y la cultura anterior, a la que desplazaron cuando llegaron al Peloponeso, alrededor del 1000 a. C. [PARAGRAPH:1]Además de las historias de los dioses, la religión helénica estaba repleta de grandes historias sobre las hazañas de los héroes, muchos de los cuales estaban emparentados con los dioses. Abundan las narraciones acerca de figuras como Hércules, Perseo, Jasón y los personajes de la Ilíada. Estos humanos solían relacionarse con los dioses y, a veces, hasta los superaban. Los griegos sentían gran estima por estos héroes, especialmente por los personajes "nobles", como por ejemplo Aquiles. [PARAGRAPH:1]Aunque algunos griegos cultivados tenían sus dudas sobre la existencia de los dioses, la mayoría no cuestionaba la validez de las historias. Los griegos utilizaban su religión para explicar el mundo natural y sus propios orígenes. Desde trazar los orígenes del propio linaje o la fundación de una ciudad hasta los actos de un dios era motivo de gran orgullo. [PARAGRAPH:1]La arqueología y el análisis lingüístico sugieren que la religión helénica estuvo muy influida por otras religiones. Por poner un ejemplo, el Zeus griego, el Júpiter romano, el Tyr germano y el Dyaus sánscrito son todos dioses del cielo que comparten un origen indoeuropeo común en un pasado lejano. Otros dioses procedían de religiones de Oriente Próximo (o habían recibido importantes influencias de ellas): Afrodita poseía una función muy similar a la de las diosas semíticas Ishtar y Astarté. Durante el período helenístico y después de él, la religión griega se extendió por gran parte del Mediterráneo y Oriente Próximo, lo que influyó en muchas de las religiones existentes y originó nuevos cultos mistéricos y sincréticos. Aunque la religión helénica ya no cuenta con seguidores, sigue siendo una gran fuente de inspiración para artistas del mundo entero.

TEXT.English: [TAB]Jainism is an Indian religion that prescribes a path of non-violence towards all living beings. Its philosophy and practice emphasize the necessity of self-effort to move the soul towards divine consciousness and liberation. Any soul that has conquered its own inner enemies and achieved the state of supreme being is called a jina ("conqueror" or "victor"). The ultimate status of these perfect souls is called siddha. Jainism is also referred to as shramana dharma (self-reliant) or the "path of the niganthas" (those without attachments or aversions) by ancient texts. Jain doctrine teaches that Jainism has always existed and will always exist, although historians date the foundation of the organized or present form of Jainism to sometime between the 9th and the 6th century BC. Like most ancient Indian religions, Jainism has its roots from the Indus Valley Civilization, reflecting native spirituality prior to the Indo-Aryan migration into India. Other scholars suggested the shramana traditions were separate and contemporaneous with Indo-Aryan religious practices of the historical Vedic religion.[PARAGRAPH:1]Contemporary Jainism is a small but influential religious minority with as many as 4.2 million followers in India, and successful growing immigrant communities in North America, Western Europe, the Far East, Australia and elsewhere. Jains have significantly influenced and contributed to ethical, political and economic spheres in India. Jains have an ancient tradition of scholarship and have the highest degree of literacy for a religious community in India. Jain libraries are the oldest in the country.

[TAB]Zoroastrianism is a religion and philosophy based on the teachings of prophet Zoroaster (also known as Zarathustra, in Avestan). It was probably founded some time before the 6th century BC in Iran. The term Zoroastrianism is, in general usage, essentially synonymous with Mazdaism (the worship of Ahura Mazda, exalted by Zoroaster as the supreme divine authority).[PARAGRAPH:2]In Zoroastrianism, the Creator Ahura Mazda is all good, and no evil originates from Him. Thus, in Zoroastrianism good and evil have distinct sources, with evil (druj) trying to destroy the creation of Mazda (asha), and good trying to sustain it. Mazda is not immanent in the world, and His creation is represented by the Amesha Spentas and the host of other Yazatas, through whom the works of God are evident to humanity, and through whom worship of Mazda is ultimately directed. The most important texts of the religion are those of the Avesta, of which a significant portion has been lost, and mostly only the liturgies of which have survived. The lost portions are known of only through references and brief quotations in the later works, primarily from the 9th to 11th centuries.[PARAGRAPH:2]Zoroastrianism is of great antiquity. In some form, it served as the national- or state religion of a significant portion of the Iranian people for many centuries before it was gradually marginalized by Islam from the 7th century onwards. The political power of the pre-Islamic Iranian dynasties lent Zoroastrianism immense prestige in ancient times, and some of its leading doctrines were adopted by other religious systems.
